questions.question: What is the first thing you need to do when you're fixing a game and you need to open it up?
questions.answer: Power off the game.

questions.question: What is the first thing you need to do when you clock in for the day?
questions.answer: Do your toolbox meeting, and sign out your keys and staff card as soon as you receive them.

questions.question: Who do we need to CC when sending an e-mail about ordering parts?
questions.answer: AM Tech Support, AM Tech Training, AM Regional Tech, GM, AGM

questions.question: After sending in a PO to a Vendor, what should you do?
questions.answer: Add a comment on the PO that says you sent it in. That way everyone can see from a glance that it was already sent in and we don't double up on any POs.

questions.question: Where can we find a list of down games?
questions.answer: At the AM/Redemption POS. Click "Functions", then "Machines", then swipe your staff card, then select "Out of Service."

questions.question: When should you add a game to R1NK? When should you mark something as Critical?
questions.answer:
Any time we notice an issue with a game, it should be added to R1NK. This includes small things like LEDs that stopped functioning, all the way up to games that are broken or safety risks.
You should mark something as "Critical/Broken" when the game is on our down games list.

questions.question: What should you do after we get a part delivery?
questions.answer: Scan the packing slip, find the PO on Kintone, upload the packing slip to the PO, mark the date and quantity of items received, then move the status of the PO forward.

questions.question: What if we get a part delivery, but it doesn't have everything we ordered on the PO?
questions.answer: Sometimes POs show up in multiple separate boxes. If the packing slip says the items are on backorder, then mark the delivery status as "Backorder" on the PO. If the packing slip does not mention the missing items at all, it probably will show up in a separate box, so you can fill out the PO with the items we have received, and then save it until we get the rest. (You can add a comment to the PO as well to clarify that we didn't just make a mistake filling everything out.)

questions.question: What are tech reports and where do we submit them?
questions.answer: Tech reports are things that corporate wants us to show proof that we finished, and we submit them on Kintone under the FA tab.

questions.question: How often do we need to do Risk Spot? When is it due?
questions.answer: Risk Spot is done once a week. It is due before each weekend.

questions.question: What do the different colors mean on the Risk Spot report?
questions.answer:
• Orange: Critical. Turn off the Swiper, add to R1NK and try to fix ASAP. Orange means there is a safety risk, so even if you can not fix the issue immediately, you need to make the area safe. For example, if the safety risk is a damaged part that we don't have extras of, remove the part, cover any holes, and order a replacement.
  • Yellow: High. Turn off the swiper and add to R1NK. Fix soon.
  • White: Add to R1NK, but swiper can stay on.

questions.question: Can you name the different types of PPE that we use here?
questions.answer:
• Eye protection (goggles)
  • Head protection (hard hat, bump cap)
  • Ear protection (ear plugs)
  • Hand protection (work gloves, insulated gloves, cutting gloves, nitrile gloves)
  • Masks
  • Back Brace
  • Knee Pads
  • Steel Toe Boots

questions.question: Can you give an example of when you would use each of the above mentioned PPEs?
questions.answer:
A non-exhaustive list:
  • Eye protection
    • Working with chemicals (to avoid splashing)
    • Soldering (molten solder can splash)
    • Grinding/Drilling (shards from what you're working on can fly towards your face)
  • Head protection
    • Working under the lanes
    • Working inside a game
    • Generally anything where you're in an enclosed space and risk hitting your head
  • Ear protection
    • Working behind the lanes
  • Hand protection
    • Work Gloves
      • Working behind the lanes
      • Moving games
      • Breaking down pallets
      • Soldering
    • Insulated Gloves
      • Metering Voltage
      • Installing/Removing a Drop Cable
      • Generally any time you're working with electricity.
    • Cutting Gloves
      • Cutting
    • Nitrile Gloves
      • Handling chemicals
      • Cleaning
  • Masks
    • Sanding
    • Soldering
    • Handling chemicals
  • Back Brace
    • Lifting heavy things
  • Knee Pads
    • Really any situation where you're working on your knees. There are tons.
  • Steel Toe Boots
    • Always. This is part of the mechanic uniform.
    .

questions.question: How should ladders be stored?
questions.answer: Ladders should be stored by chaining them against a wall.

questions.question: How could you find information on various chemicals that we use in the store?
questions.answer: SDS (Safety Data Sheets) binders

questions.question: Why do items need to be stored below 18 inches from the ceiling?
questions.answer: To make sure sprinklers can effectively extinguish any fires. Storing items too high can block sprinklers.

questions.question: What is the difference between AC and DC?
questions.answer: AC (Alternating Current) flows in two directions, and DC (Direct Current) only flows in one direction. AC is what we provide through wall/drop cable outlets, and DC is what we would generally find inside our game cabinets and other electronics. This is because AC is cheaper to transport over long distances, so that is what gets provided to our building, but we need DC to run the components in our games and other devices due to its nature of only flowing in one direction. So we take the AC from the wall, and each machine will convert it to DC to be able to function.

questions.question: How much voltage (and what type) should we expect from a wall/drop cable outlet?
questions.answer: 120VAC

questions.question: What multimeter setting would you use if you want to check if a switch is good?
questions.answer:
#5 is the best for testing continuity.
While #4 and #6 could be used to test continuity, technically those settings are for checking resistance and testing diodes respectively, whereas #5 is explicitly a setting to check continuity.

questions.question: What multimeter setting would you use if you want to check if a wall/drop cable outlet is good?
questions.answer: #1 is the setting to check AC voltage

questions.question: What multimeter setting would you use if you want to check if a power supply is outputting the correct voltage?
questions.answer: #2 checks DC voltage, which is what PSUs output.

questions.question: What can you do to make sure you don't strip the head of a screw?
questions.answer:
Make sure you're using the right size. For example a P2 bit might strip a P3 screw head, or if you're using a metric hex bit for an imperial screw you risk stripping it.
You also risk stripping a head if you continue screwing it in after it's already secure, which can easily happen if you are using an electric driver with too much power.

questions.question: What is this tool used for? What is it called?
questions.answer: This tool is called "Snap Ring Pliers," and it is used for removing and installing snap rings

questions.question: What is this tool used for? What is it called?
questions.answer: This tool is called a molex crimper, and it is for crimping molex connectors onto wires.

questions.question: What is this tool used for? What is it called?
questions.answer: This tool is called a crimper, and it is for crimping wire terminals and connectors such as the ones shown in the photo.

questions.question: What is the issue with this crimp?
questions.answer: The conductor is sticking too far out. The crimp should be just covering the conductor, and the insulation should be inside the sleeve right before the crimp.

questions.question: What is the issue with this crimp?
questions.answer: The wrong part of the crimper was used. The pointy section of the crimper is intended for non-insulated terminals. The open section of the crimper should be used on insulated terminals. While it may look and feel like a nice and secure crimp, crimping a wire like this can damage it, and cause it to break much easier.

questions.question: What is the issue with this crimp?
questions.answer: Too much of the wire was stripped, and the insulation isn't secure in the outer crimp. This can eventually cause the connector to break off from the conductor flexing around. Keeping the insulation in the outer crimp adds structure to the connection that allows it to last longer.

questions.question: What is the issue with this crimp?
questions.answer: The wire was pushed too far into the terminal. The conductor should be inside the inner crimp to ensure that the terminal is actually connected to the wire. If you do a continuity test on this connector it might actually return good results as the conductor does extend past the crimp, but the connection would be iffy and could be very inconsistent while in use.

questions.question: What are these tools used for? What are they called? (They're the same tool, just different sizes.)
questions.answer: These are molex removers. They are used to remove molex terminals from their connectors without damaging the terminal or the connector. They work by going over the "lock tangs" (the fins that are sticking out of the terminal which hold the terminal in place inside the connector), which lets you push the terminal back through the connector without breaking it.

questions.question: What is this tool used for? What is it called?
questions.answer: This tool is called a data cable crimper, and it is for crimping networking cables. It has an 8-pin slot and a 6-pin slot, though we'll pretty much always be using the 8-pin. It also has a blade that can help you strip a network cable.

questions.question: What is the difference between an impact driver and a non-impact drill?
questions.answer:
While both tools may look like they operate the same, impact drivers actually use a sort of hammering force in addition to the torque that you're familiar with. This allows it to be used on more heavy duty fasteners as the hammering force can allow the driver to maintain a solid grip with the head of a screw. However, this extra force can come with a cost. Using an impact driver on lighter duty fasteners can cause damage. For example, you should always avoid using impact drivers on plexi because you can risk cracking the plexi from the additional force.
While impact drivers may look smaller, and appear to be the weaker of the two options, the impact driver can afford to be so small because it's a more specialized tool. You can see in the comparison pictures that the non-impact drill driver has many settings it can choose between, which requires a larger build.

questions.question: What is the name of the pictured object?
questions.answer: Network Switch

questions.question: What are the different networks we have for our games?
questions.answer: Konami JP, Konami USA, SEGA, Namco, Taito, and "Free".

questions.question: What color is associated with each of those networks?
questions.answer: Konami JP: Red, Konami USA: Orange, SEGA: Blue, Namco: Yellow, Taito: Green, Free: White

questions.question: What is this tool used for?
questions.answer: This is a network cable tester, which is used for testing network cables. One end is removable, which allows you to test a cable even through long distances. For example, you can test one side of a cable at a game or network switch, and test the other side all the way over in the server room.

questions.question: What should you should check if a game is offline?
questions.answer:
• Check if the network cable is plugged in (both sides -- game and network switch)
  • Check if the signal light is lit up where the cable is plugged in.
  • If no light at all, check if the network switch is powered on.
  • Use a network cable tester to see if the network cable is still in good condition.
  • Check if the game is currently undergoing maintenance (for certain games like the NESiCAxLive cabinets this is definitely the most likely scenario).

questions.question: How much voltage do we usually use to power our swipers?
Why is cable management important when dealing with swiper harnesses?
questions.answer: If harnesses are not properly secured, then you risk damaging them when closing service doors.

questions.question: What is a non-ticketing report and where can you find it?
questions.answer: If we have a redemption game with recorded plays, but no ticket payout, we will get an e-mail letting us know. You can find it on the main store e-mail (not the events laptop) and usually it gets sent off once a week. If there is no e-mail to be found, then that means all our games appear to be ticketing properly.

questions.question: What are some things that could be the issue if a game shows up on our non-ticketing report?
questions.answer:
• The game settings could be wrong.
  • The swiper harness could be damaged.
  • The swiper itself could be damaged.
  • People could be bad at the game, so they just didn't win any tickets.

questions.question: How could you fix each of those issues?
questions.answer:
• The game settings could be wrong:
    • (If we have multiple of that cabinet): compare settings with other cabinets that are working and match them.
    • (If we only have one of that cabinet): Check Game Directory on Kintone for suggested settings.
  • The swiper harness could be damaged:
    • Re-do the swiper wiring.
  • The swiper itself could be damaged:
    • Replace the swiper.
  • People could be bad at the game, so they just didn't win any tickets:
    • We actually can solve this issue if the game has a mercy tickets option. We could set the game to always give at least a pittance of tickets for every play, regardless of how well someone did. For example, just 1 or 2 tickets. This would allow the game to ticket even when people aren't winning, which would let us know more accurately if a game is ticketing correctly or not.

questions.question: Before installing a swiper, what should you record so we can finish the swiper installation?
questions.answer: The MAC Address on the back of the swiper. We need to update that in back office.

questions.question: After installing a freshly opened swiper (and doing what you need according to the previous question), what else do you need to do so that the swiper can finally be up and running?
questions.answer: Call intercard and have them open the TFTP server so the swiper can download its reader code.

questions.question: What does it mean when you see maximum payout on a swiper?
questions.answer: Maximum payout puts a temporary hold on the "unawarded tickets" that go beyond the "max points" setting we have set on back office. Once the "max points" is reached, further tickets are put on hold until someone with a staff card swipes them, after which they will go to the customer. This allows us to catch errors with ticketing before they become a problem, because if a game or swiper is ticketing way too much, then we can fix the issue before a customer can take advantage of it.

questions.question: Do you think it would be okay to swipe on this swiper? Why or why not?
questions.answer: No. That is way too many tickets and no game should be awarding that many all at once. This is a clear sign that there is something wrong with the ticketing, and we either need to replace the swiper, the harness, or fix the game (some troubleshooting will be required to find the exact cause). As a side note, if this was a video instead of a picture, you would actually see the unawarded tickets still continuously ticking up, which is another sign something is wrong.

questions.question: After you swipe on a maximum payout, what happens to the tickets?
questions.answer: They go to the last person who played the machine.

questions.question: When should you swipe on a maximum payout? And why?
questions.answer: Once the game is no longer awarding tickets, if the maximum payout seems like a reasonable number, then you can swipe on a maximum payout. Never swipe when it is still ticking out. Until it is done counting tickets, we can not be sure if it's okay or not.

questions.question: What is the first thing you should do when you answer a bowling call once you're behind the lanes?
questions.answer: Hold the reset button to put the sweep down, then switch off the pinsetter.

questions.question: What does "LOTO" mean?
questions.answer: Lock Out Tag Out. It means to unplug the power cable from the NEXGEN Controller, and put the plug in a locked container so that nobody can power the machine on while it's being worked on.

questions.question: If you need to get under the table to work on something, what do you need to do before you get under there?
questions.answer:
• Put the cheese block down in the lane to make sure no balls can get through.
  • Put the sweep down because you don't want it to fall down on you while you're working under it.
  • Turn the pinsetter off. LOTO
  • Put jack stands under the table.

questions.question: What does an error 1-10 mean? What are some things that could cause it?
questions.answer:
Errors 1-10 are a pin timeout error, which means that a pin holder was waiting for too long for a pin to load into it. Some things that could cause this error are:
  • A jam on the distributor that is preventing the pins from moving to available pin stations.
  • A faulty pin station that isn't releasing its pin to the pin holder.
  • A faulty pin holder that isn't opening its arms to hit the release lever.
  • The distributor shark isn't switching directions, so all the pins are going into one side.
  • There aren't enough pins in the machine to load all available pin stations.

questions.question: If a lane keeps giving off an error 50-59 in diag, what does that mean?
questions.answer:
Errors 50-59 are a "Pin not detected in Diagnostics" error, but more specifically it's when the pinholder goes to check for a pin that should be standing, but can't find it. It could mean that a spotting tong has failed to pick up a pin, or a pin holder dropped a pin early.
It is also important to note that these errors will not show up during normal gameplay because the pinsetter can't know which pins should be standing in that case. So it's important to regularly run the lanes through DIAG to be able to catch these errors happening.

questions.question: What is the first thing you should look for if you get a call for a "J1" error?
questions.answer: A pin that is stuck on the table, which would prevent the pin holders from going down or back up properly.

questions.question: What part of the pinsetter pertains to error 75? What's a common cause for this error?
questions.answer: Error 75 means the sweep didn't hit the switch that it should be hitting when it's all the way down. This is often caused by a pin being stuck under the sweep.

questions.question: What does error "EJ" stand for? What is a likely cause for this error?
questions.answer: Elevator Jam. This could be caused by a pin getting stuck in the elevator, preventing it from moving, or it could be caused by a jam in the distributor that is backed up to the elevator.

questions.question: If you go to fix a ball jam, and you need to clear the ball return area behind the lanes, what do you need to do to ensure the accelerator motor stops running so you can safely resolve the issue?
questions.answer: Turn both pinsetters off. (Also make sure the sweeps are down first.)

questions.question: Where are all the places you could look for cleaning supplies?
questions.answer:
• Facilities Room
  • CO2 Room
  • Laundry Room

questions.question: What should you do after fixing a crane?
questions.answer: Let amusement know that it's ready to be turned back on so they can check the settings and make sure it's good for customers to play. Remember to edit the note on the down games list so it's clear that the ball is in amusement's court. (You can do that by turning the swiper back on then turning it off again with an updated note.) Amusement needs to keep a specific payout across all their cranes, and if you turn a crane on too soon you risk that crane not having the correct settings which could either make the payout way too high or way too low. Always communicate with amusement.

questions.question: Before giving out a prize from a UFO8, what should you do first?
questions.answer: Double check the photo and instructions on the top of the crane. Sometimes customers think they won, but they only did part of what's needed to win a prize.

questions.question: Should you update clickers after handing out crane prizes?
questions.answer: No. Amusement updates the clickers as they stock the cranes, so we don't need to touch them at all.

questions.question: What should you do if a customer wants a different prize from a crane?
questions.answer:
• If they already won the prize: No can do. They have to keep the prize they won.
  • If they haven't won the prize yet (everything is still in the machine): You can swap prizes as long as everything stays in the same machine and side of the machine.
    • For example, if there is a green plush and a pink plush in UFO8 #4 on the left side, and the green plush is currently out on the playfield, you can swap the green plush on the playfield with a pink plush in the back if the customer asks. However, you can not take a plush from the right side of the machine. It needs to stay on the same side and machine.

questions.question: What is a "decoy" in a crane?
questions.answer:
The decoy helps amusement by allowing them to keep consistent settings while swapping out plushes, so they don't need to adjust the strength of the claw every single time the prizes change.
Sometimes, often in Chibi Cranes, the prizes are difficult for the claw to grab, so putting a decoy plush in a chibi crane allows amusement to set up a prize that the customers can actually win.
Never give the decoy out to a customer. Always check the back of the crane to see what the prize actually is, and hand over the appropriate prize. In Gemini and Deca cranes the decoy is usually obvious as it's a giant yellow disc with big text on it. However in chibi cranes, they usually use damaged plush with a label on it as a decoy, so it can be easy to mistake for a prize if you're not paying attention.

questions.question: What can you do if a crane malfunctions while a customer plays it, but you aren't able to quickly fix it so they can try again?
questions.answer: We can not offer credit refunds for cranes, so you should always give the customer a free play on a different crane of their choice. Do not send them back to the counter.

questions.question: What kind of current would this cable likely carry?
questions.answer: AC. While technically it's just wires, and you could run whatever you want through it, you can get an idea of its intended use because of the color coding of the wires. In this case, the White, Green, and Black combo is indicative of an AC cable.

questions.question: How much voltage should we expect if we plugged this into something?
questions.answer: 120VAC because that's how much AC voltage our building supplies.

questions.question: What is the term for the white wire?
questions.answer: Neutral (N)

questions.question: What is the term for the black wire?
questions.answer: Live (L)

questions.question: What is the term for the green wire?
questions.answer: Earth Ground

questions.question: What is this part called?
questions.answer: Transformer

questions.question: What is the purpose of this part?
questions.answer: Steps up or steps down voltage (in this case it's being used to step down)

questions.question: Is the input voltage AC or DC?
questions.answer: AC. The input is coming pretty much directly from our wall/drop cable, which is 120VAC.

questions.question: Is the output voltage AC or DC?
questions.answer: AC again. Remember that transformers don't convert voltage. They simply step up or step down voltage. It goes in AC, and comes out AC still.

questions.question: What do the Blue Wires represent? (Input or Output?)
questions.answer: Output. The transformer is sending 100VAC into the rest of the cabinet.

questions.question: What do the Orange Wires represent? (Input or Output?)
questions.answer: Input. This is basically directly connected from the wall outlet so that is what we are providing to the transformer.

questions.question: What does "0V" mean?
questions.answer: Neutral

questions.question: Which wire is missing here from one of our standard 3-wire AC cables? Where would it go?
questions.answer: The Earth Ground wire is missing. It would generally be attached in some way directly to a metal section of the cabinet so it can divert electricity away safely.

questions.question:
If we were to replace a monitor in a game we might have to deal with having two separate cables.
One for the game and then another for the new monitor we installed.
How could we solve that problem using this component?
questions.answer: Strip the monitor power cable, then put the Live wire onto the 120V terminal, put the Neutral wire onto the 0V terminal, and then find a spot in the cabinet to attach the Earth Ground wire. Now the monitor should start up as soon as the game gets power, and the whole cabinet still only uses the one outlet.

questions.question: What is this part called?
questions.answer: PSU (Power Supply Unit)

questions.question: What is the purpose of this part?
questions.answer:
Converts AC to DC.
You might think "It's a Power Supply so it supplies power," but technically we're supplying power to the power supply. The power supply is converting that AC voltage that we supply into DC voltage that the game can utilize.

questions.question: What is the input voltage? (And is that AC or DC?)
questions.answer: 120VAC. Power supplies are generally going to either be pretty much directly connected from the wall outlet, or on the other end of a transformer, both of which are AC power.

questions.question: What is the output?
If we had something that required 12V 10A, could we use this?
questions.answer: Yes. The game will take the 10A it needs. Even though the PSU has 17A available, not all of it necessarily will be supplied when powering whatever it's connected to.

questions.question: If we had something that required 5V 10A, could we use this?
questions.answer: No. The voltage is wrong, so it will providing way too much power to the components it's connected to, which could easily cause them to break.

questions.question: If we had something that required 12V 20A, could we use this?
questions.answer: No. This power supply is only providing 17A, so it does not provide enough current to be able to operate something that requires 20A.

questions.question: If we plugged something in to the 12V output and we were only getting 10V from it, what should we do?
questions.answer: We would start by turning up the ADJ dial, which lets us adjust the voltage output of the power supply. If we still weren't able to reach that 12V output after turning up the dial, then the PSU is probably faulty and will need to be replaced.

questions.question: What do the yellow wires represent?
What do the thin black wires represent?
questions.answer: Ground (-V)

questions.question: What does the thick black wire represent?
questions.answer: Live (L)

questions.question: What does the green wire represent?
questions.answer: Earth Ground

questions.question: What does the white wire represent?
questions.answer: Neutral (N)

questions.question: How much voltage do you need to power a swiper?
questions.answer: Usually 12V, but Intercard swipers can be powered with 11-24VDC.

questions.question: How much voltage would we usually expect from a coin up line?
questions.answer: 5VDC

questions.question:
We get a new game and we need to wire up the swiper ourselves. 
We can only find +5VDC and +24VDC. What do we do?
questions.answer: Hook up 24V to power the swiper and 5V is probably the coin line. Intercard swipers can be powered on up to 24VDC.

questions.question: Can you name the red wire on the harness?
questions.answer: +12V (Swiper power)

questions.question: Can you name the black wire on the harness?
questions.answer: Ground for the swiper power

questions.question: Can you name the purple wire on the harness?
questions.answer: Coin Signal

questions.question: Can you name the grey wire on the harness?
questions.answer: Coin Ground

questions.question: Can you name the blue wire on the harness?
questions.answer: Token Monitor (usually referred to as "prize monitor" since we use it for monitoring crane payouts, but the swiper harness is labeled "Token Monitor")

questions.question: Can you name the yellow wire on the harness?
questions.answer: Coin Monitor (we have no reason to use this one)

questions.question: Can you name the white wire on the harness?
questions.answer: Ticket Enable

questions.question: Can you name the green wire on the harness?
questions.answer: Ticket Notch

questions.question: What is special about the 4-pin connector on the harness?
questions.answer: It's called a "Ticket Harness", and it's designed to just plug right into a redemption game's ticket dispenser, but if no such connector already exists inside a game, we can still make one ourselves.

questions.question: We get a brand new redemption game. Which wires do we need to hook up to the game?
questions.answer: The whole ticket harness, Purple, Grey. We need the ticket harness to power the swiper, and to allow the game to be able to pay out tickets. In addition to that, we of course need to hook up the coin lines so the game will coin up when someone swipes their card.

questions.question: We get a brand new photobooth. Which wires do we need to hook up to the game?
questions.answer: Red, Black, Purple, Grey. Photobooths don't pay out tickets, so the only thing we need to worry about is powering the swiper, and allowing people to coin the game up by swiping.

questions.question: We get a brand new crane. Which wires do we need to hook up to the game?
questions.answer: Red, Black, Purple, Grey, Blue. Cranes don't pay out tickets, so we don't need the rest of the ticket harness, but we do use the "token" monitor wire to track prize payouts. So we need to connect swiper power, coin lines, as well as the token monitor.

questions.question: What does "L2" mean?
questions.answer: Phase 2. More specifically, AC power can be transported across multiple "phases" by offsetting the frequency of the AC. The specifics don't matter for us, but in short this lets us use one rail to transport three separate lines of AC, saving us lots of space for providing power to our machines.

questions.question: Why might that label be important?
questions.answer: So we can balance out power that we consume across multiple phases on a rail. If we see a lot of "L2" drop cables for example, then we can try and look for an L1 or L3 instead (if we have any available).

questions.question: If you see a colored sticker instead of "L1," "L2," or "L3," what does that mean?
questions.answer: Black = L1, Red = L2, Blue = L3

questions.question: What if you see multiple colored stickers?
questions.answer: Multiple breakers, multiple phases in one drop cable

questions.question: If you're removing a drop cable, what should you do first after you get up the ladder?
questions.answer: Power it off

questions.question: What should you always do after installing a drop cable? (After you turned it on)
questions.answer: Test it with a multimeter

questions.question: What is the maximum current that we want on a single drop cable?
questions.answer: 20A, but ideally we always stay under 20A closer to the 16A range if possible.

questions.question: If we get a new game and it doesn't show how many Amps it takes, what other value would we see instead?
questions.answer: Watts (You might also see voltage, but we can always assume voltage is 120V)

questions.question: Using the other value stated in the answer above, how could we figure out the amps?
questions.answer: Amps = Watts / Voltage

questions.question:
Let's say we have a drop cable with one free outlet, and it currently has 14 amps worth of games plugged into it.
We get a new game that takes 850 watts, can we plug it into that drop cable?
questions.answer:
No.
14 + (850/120) = 21.08A, but one drop cable should only ever have a maximum of 20A.

questions.question: Which of these locks are in the correct orientation according to Round1 guidelines?
questions.answer: A, C, F are all correct. Round1 lock guidelines state that locks should only ever point up or right. Generally the direction will be decided based on the hole the lock goes into. If multiple orientations are possible, then the lock should face to the right. In the case that you're using a 2-pole lock, then one pole should face to the right, and the other should face up.

questions.question: What size sockets would you need for installing/removing a lock?
questions.answer: 22mm deep socket for removing the large nut, and a 11mm socket for the nut that secures the cam.
